snippet: In the Pashtun slums of Karachi, Pakistan, militants have gunned down police officers, assaulted poorly defended police stations and dispatched suicide bombers to assassinate top police commanders.
abstract: One hundred police officers in Karachi, Pakistan, have been killed in 2014, putting force on track to exceed 2013 toll of 166 police deaths; officials say killings are proof that guerrilla war against Taliban, which was once confined to tribal belt in the northwest of the country, has spread to the country's largest city.

byline.original: By ZIA ur-REHMAN and DECLAN WALSH
byline.contributor: Zia ur-Rehman reported from Karachi, and Declan Walsh from London. Hasan Abdullah contributed reporting from Karachi.

lead_paragraph: In the Pashtun slums of Karachi, Pakistan, militants have gunned down police officers, assaulted poorly defended police stations and dispatched suicide bombers to assassinate top police commanders.

headline.main: Killings Rise in Karachi as Taliban Target Police
headline.print_headline: Killings Rise in Karachi as Taliban Target Police
